awd_titl_txt: NSF Convergence Accelerator Track G: 5G Hidden Operations through Securing Traffic (GHOST)
awd_abstract_narration:
: The proliferation of 5G networks around the world presents an attractive opportunity for U.S. government organizations, nongovernmental humanitarian aid organizations, and private sector enterprises to take advantage of indigenous 5G networks to eliminate the costs of installing and maintaining an alternate communications infrastructure. However, in many areas of the world, 5G networks are deployed and operated by organizations that are untrusted and potentially hostile to the U.S. In these environments, new security technologies are needed to secure operations.  The 5G Hidden Operations through Securing Traffic (GHOST) project provides four layers of security.  First, GHOST protects against end-user and networking devices from being compromised by a hostile network.  Second, GHOST anonymizes individual identities and obscures user locations.  Third, GHOST prevents traffic analysis that could reveal operational plans and activities by anonymizing communication connections and introducing “GHOST” traffic into the network to maintain a constant level of activity.  Finally, the GHOST project will further obfuscate traffic analysis by injecting “false flag” traffic that models real operations to confuse and mislead analysis. The GHOST technology will enable organizations ranging from the U.S. military to private entities to securely operate over indigenous 5G networks, regardless of the politics of the network operators.

The GHOST project addresses the core intellectual challenge of providing secure communications resistant to penetration and traffic analysis over untrusted networks. The GHOST project considers the network as a black box that is assumed to be operated by a hostile agent. Addressing the challenge will yield four intellectual benefits to the research and operational communities. 
•	First, the GHOST project will deliver technology that will protect end-user devices and non-indigenous networking equipment from penetration and compromise. The technology secures devices at the hardware level through the use of Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs).  The idea behind a TEE is that anything coming from outside the chip boundary is untrusted. TEEs enforce this trusted boundary by implementing integrity verification of data and code and encrypting them once they cross the trusted boundary. 
•	Second, the GHOST project will deliver technology to anonymize or disguise end-user identities, locations, and communications endpoints.   End-user identities will be protected using software defined credentials.  Locations are protected using geo-spatial identity management.  Communications connections are protected by peer-to-peer anonymization.
•	Third, the GHOST project will deliver technology to overlay normal traffic with “GHOST” traffic — essentially network white noise — to obfuscate traffic analysis.    
•	Fourth, the GHOST project will deliver technology to model and generate “false flag” traffic.  Through monitoring and simulation, models of traffic patterns associated with specific operations will be generated.  “False flag” traffic injected into the network will reflect the traffic associated with a particular operation and be convincing to any observers.

GHOST technology will benefit end-users of any network, not just untrusted networks. The primary criteria for success of the GHOST project will be:
•	Device protection from network operator attacks;
•	The obfuscation of user identities, locations, and communications connections;
•	The obfuscation of traffic patterns;
•	The injection of “false flag” traffic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
5G is emerging and is expected to soon become near-ubiquitous around the world. Hence, U.S. government organizations such as the military and State Department, as well as nongovernmental humanitarian aid organizations, and private sector enterprises should take advantage of indigenous 5G networks to eliminate the costs of installing and maintaining an alternate communications infrastructure. However, in many areas of the world, 5G networks are deployed and operated by organizations that are untrusted and potentially hostile to the U.S. Even in the US, it’s been recently reported that Chinese hackers have deeply penetrated US carriers to access their lawful intercept tools for targeted voice, text, location, and metadata interception. In these environments, new security technologies are needed to enable secure operations over untrusted networks.

The objective of the 5G Hidden Operations through Securing Traffic (GHOST) project is to enable secure use of 5G by preventing an untrusted network operator or external actor with network access from analyzing 5G activity to reveal details about individuals, organizations, and their activities, as well as to protect devices from compromise. GHOST is extending the discipline of cybersecurity by looking beyond securing communications to preventing pattern-of-life analysis and traffic analysis from revealing the activities of individuals and organizations. Providing resistance to network analysis requires tools and technologies which are different from approaches such as encryption and onion routing. The GHOST developments will have impact on other networks beyond cellular, such as Wi-Fi. Additionally, GHOST will impact the discipline of microarchitectural security through advancements in development and application of trusted execution environments (TEEs).

GHOST demonstrated means for protecting users by obfuscating identities and activities. GHOST demonstrated dynamic swapping of 5G subscriber and device IDs. Additionally, GHOST investigated associating unique patterns of 5G activity, called “individual activity patterns,” or IAPs, with each ID. IAPs execute on user devices and overlay the actual activities of a user with a different pattern of activity. For example, one ID might be associated with an IAP that characterizes an 18-year old gamer, while another ID might have an IAP that characterizes a 24-year old new parent. In the end product, when an ID is swapped on a device, the IAP will change as well. Together, GHOST terms the combination of an ID and an IAP a “persona.”

GHOST demonstrated technology to shape observed 5G activity through the injection of false, or “ghost,” activity to obfuscate pattern-of-life and traffic analysis. Significant intelligence can be gleaned by simple observing overall patterns of 5G activity. For example, diurnal patterns of activity can be used to identify living areas vs. work areas. GHOST demonstrated the introduction of ghost activity to obscure actual activity. Additionally, GHOST extended the concept of activity shaping by introducing decoy activity to mislead observers. For example, to deceive or confuse an adversary, the U.S. military might wish to make it appear as if U.S. forces were deployed in multiple locations by deploying decoy devices that would create network activity virtually identical to the actual deployment. In the end product, GHOST will enable organizations to design and execute obfuscation and deception operations.

GHOST demonstrated technology to protect end-user devices from penetration and compromise in the event of loss or capture. When end-user devices are lost or captured, the existence and functionality of GHOST must be protected from penetration or compromise. GHOST explored the use of Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs), and investigated mechanisms for providing secure memory in TEEs.

Over the course of Phase 1, the GHOST conducted interviews with multiple stakeholders, including personnel from military, law enforcement, non-governmental organizations, and cybersecurity to obtain feedback on the concept. Without exception, the feedback was positive and included suggestions on how to extend the concept.
